message: I wouldn't say nobody but I definitely agree there is too much broadcasting and not enough listening

For the most part I use twitter to share original content that some people care about and if they don't they don't need to follow me. Likewise, I follow people that I enjoy seeing their posts or I unfollow them. http://twitter.com/craigshipp
I wouldn't say "everybody" - it also depends on who you follow, too.
It is our responsibility to promote good people and ignore bad ones. Twitter is for sharing, people. Twitter is for sharing people.
Hmm...on brand Facebook pages especially, @DrThomasHo. It's very easy to just churn out content and not engage fans.
A few months ago I had the same "revelation" about Facebook: http://drthomasho.amplify.com/2011/01/13/a-contrarian-view-of-facebook-is-anyone-paying-attention-momento/
I would say that brands, on the whole, are using it much more as a broadcast medium.

This phenomenon is precisely the reason why I prefer tools for curation such as http://amplify.com but unfortunately few others appreciate their value as you can see from my personal experience on Amplify: http://drthomasho.amplify.com/

I understand what you mean, but I have found that listening is a product of earning attention in addition to just getting permission (freind, like, or follow). Too many just concentrait on the numbers building game instead of building a quality community. If your interesting in the complete thought you can check out. http://bit.ly/fUzr3H
@DrThomasHo - didn't realize you were in this chain too! I think I've chatted with you on Twitter before. You have that Central FL paper.li set up :P
This is true but not for everyone. I listen first then give my reply on whatever topic they tweet. I think you get long term followers that way.

@kevinmullet exactly. At first I have to listen and to respond, before I'm heard with my own messages. It's all about: "At first you have to give, before you can get." You doesn't pay attention to others, will never get the attention of others. Social web is about "Social" - radio, tv, newspaper is about "Broadcast". Many haven't got it so far...

I feel like most of the smaller and/or companies, artists, or organizations interact with me and my personal friends on twitter. I have also noticed that by combining posts about the surface of my personal life alongside posts about my career/relevance, that people have become more interested.
@michaelwalmsley, yes, very often. But it's still an amazing platform for communicating with people.

I think it really depends on who you follow and who is following you. I used it with many friends almost like a public IM service, since with Twitter I didn't have to worry about what phone someone had (many people I know use multiple phones), what email account they're checking, etc.

I think brands/companies are starting to realize the power of listening on twitter but have a long way to go. Gary Vaynerchuk really gets it. Check out his book Thank You Economy it bring up great points about listening and the power of twitter and social media as a whole. - @ShizzMedia
Yep. And thank God! This is exactly why those people and brands that "get it", still have plenty of time before those that are just "on it" catch up.

BTW this is exactly why i built www.LiveFanChat.com/sites - we started http://www.LiveBaseballChat.com for this very reason (liken it to sitting in your living room shooting the breeze with some buddies while the game is on).

totally agree. the way i explain it is twitter is like standing on the edge of a cliff by the ocean and shouting into the wind, sometimes people hear it but realistically your odds are about the same.

To answer the question in the title - I'd say nope, not really.
Like @JohnFail said, it depends on who you're watching and following. I for one have still found plenty of interesting content by mostly listening. 
If I started building an online platform and enhancing my online presence more seriously, talking a lot would make sense, but only if I had good enough content worth tweeting. 
Then again, to use Twitter successfully you need to do some occasional listening, too. IMO one cannot be successful in Twitter without listening. Even with good content.
Interaction between you and your followers is one of the keys to a successful social media presence.  I find that active listening skills will help you go a long way in Social Media.

I wouldn't say that. For brands that I manage, I reply to everyone who mentions the brand, even if it's a negative tweet. So sometimes, someone is listening. And for my personal account, I generally get a few replies. Even when I announced I'm having a haircut ;p
@meiyingt I wish more brands would do that. Most enjoy pretending the negative tweets don't happen.

@meiyingt I really love the companies where, when someone complains about a bad experience on twitter, they go out of their way to make it right. It's a very easy way to very publicly garner user support, purely based on seeing the company actually help out their customers.
If I wanted to solve this problem and, leading by example, become a better listener, consumer and processor of appropriate twitter streams, what would I do?
[As an end-user, and not necessarily any kind of corporate representative.]
Twitter doesn't lend itself to people "listening." That's one of its weaknesses
@nevadaexile I listen to those that I follow or I wouldn't be following them.
@nevadaexile Twitter bought Tweetdeck, which is an excellent stream aggregator, so they must have plans to improve the 'listening' experience.
@craigshipp Do you find more valuable feeds than can be consumed in a single news stream?
@QuavMo I have lists and I don't hesitate to un-follow someone if I don't find their posts interesting.
@QuavMo Or they just wanted to keep UberMedia from buying it.
@QuavMo Or they just wanted to keep UberMedia from buying it.
It's mostly that they didn't want ubermedia to get it. They don't want a monopoly in their ecosystem, that's bad for business.
Yeah just like most places in the world
@rachelmarshall very true
I would love to be proven wrong but I believe Twitter missed out by not making the most of lists. Google has the jump on them now with circles.
twitter= celebrity talking and people following.
Yes it's almost like what's the point but it addictive
The option to interact exists but mostly its a stream of broadcasted info. Filtering and sorting tools are very useful.
I usually will try to engage in a dialogue on twitter. I've found its great for striking up a conversation with absolute strangers.
I usually will try to engage in a dialogue on twitter. I've found its great for striking up a conversation with absolute strangers.
Thank you for asking this question. Since knowing my Klout score I have been aiming to improve my engagement on twitter.  I wonder if its about how influential you are?
Yes. There are hardly any replies or notices that say people actually pay attention to their rambling.
